item.title: Collective emotions
item.description: From [[books/tarot for change|Tarot for Change]], [[authors/jessica dore|Jessica Dore]]: But with emotions, it‚Äôs not always clear who ‚Äúowns‚Äù them. I‚Äôve woken up heavy with the boulder of my grandmother‚Äôs grief on my chest, breathed deeply while sweating from the fire of my mother‚Äôs rage, and I could say, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs theirs, not mine,‚Äù if I wanted to, but what good would that do?

item.title: The boundary is a meeting place
item.description: From [[books/tarot for change|Tarot for Change]], [[authors/jessica dore|Jessica Dore]]: The image asks us to consider that as much as a boundary is a limit, it‚Äôs also a meeting place. A place where we identify and name what we can and cannot bring, and where we locate our edges in relationships with others.

item.title: The righting reflex
item.description: From [[books/tarot for change|Tarot for Change]], [[authors/jessica dore|Jessica Dore]]: The primary task in all healing relationships‚Äîsuch as that between a therapist and client‚Äîis to listen deeply. Conversely, traumatic relationships are ones in which people consistently deny, overlook, and avoid each other‚Äôs truths. I first learned of exquisite empathy as a graduate student seeking ways to cope with the overwhelming grief and anguish I was bearing witness to as an intern at a community mental health agency in an under-resourced community.

item.title: Emodiversity
item.description: From [[books/tarot for change|Tarot for Change]], [[authors/jessica dore|Jessica Dore]]: In 2017, positive psychology researchers published findings that suggested emodiversity‚Äîwhich they defined as ‚Äúthe breadth and relative abundance of emotions that individuals experience‚Äù‚Äîis more significant to wellness than happiness. When they asked 175 adults between the ages of forty and fifty to record their positive and negative emotions over thirty days, they discovered that those who reported a broader range of emotions had less inflammation, a biological process that has been linked to both early morbidity and mortality, but also to emotional states.

item.title: The importance of anger
item.description: From [[books/tarot for change|Tarot for Change]], [[authors/jessica dore|Jessica Dore]]: Validating fury in ourselves and others isn‚Äôt simply a means to an end of making it go away‚Äî==if your goal is to squash it, you‚Äôre not really validating anything.== Evolutionary psychology researchers have suggested a thing called ==the recalibration theory of anger==, which suggests that anger evolved to help us increase our social bargaining power and ensure that we demand better deals for ourselves when we‚Äôve either been slighted or might be again.

item.title: Moral dumbfounding
item.description: Moral judgement and moral reasoning are basically two different processes. People tend to have a knee-jerk reaction for what‚Äôs good or bad, often based more on cultural conditioning, prejudice, or gut feelings than any reasonable morality or ethics. When asked to elaborate, you get ‚Äúmoral dumbfounding,‚Äù moral reasoning made up ex-post facto to justify moral judgement.

item.title: Abuse is best recognized by the effect it has on the abused
item.description: I‚Äôm just going to paraphrase and quote this whole bit from [[books/the dominance playbook|The Dominance Playbook]] by [[authors/anton fulmen|Anton Fulmen]], because HOW this this not foundational knowledge: While there are people out there with malicious intentions, abuse can often happen when there‚Äôs no intent to harm.

item.title: Behaviorist theory
item.description: Behaviorism claims that the only thing powerful enough to spur people into action is the promise of reward or the fear of punishment. The most widely understood theoretical model of how punishment works comes from behaviorist psychology, which looks at punishment as one kind of conditioning.

item.title: Culture-bound syndrome
item.description: [[authors/jesse bering|Jesse Bering]] on symbolic disgust as a culture-bound syndrome: What induces the symbolic disgust response is defined by prevailing cultural forces. That‚Äôs to say, for the most part we‚Äôve learned to morally loathe whatever it is that we‚Äôve come to do; this information isn‚Äôt genetically inborn but socially acquired.

item.title: Erotic plasticity
item.description: How fluid is our sense of the erotic? Like neurological plasticity, probably a lot more fluid than we think. Per [[authors/jesse bering|Jesse Bering]], in [[books/perv|Perv]]: Whether it involves livestock or people, this sexual-imprinting process (in which a highly circumscribed set of erotic targets is stamped early into the individual‚Äôs brain) appears to be a decidedly male characteristic.

item.title: Moral panics and mass hysteria
item.description: Imma start collecting moral panics from the past so our current ones sound less wild. Moral of the story: humans will moral panic over just about anything üíÄ The pig-man hunts of New Haven Courtesy of [[authors/jesse bering|Jesse Bering]] in his book [[books/perv|Perv]]: You‚Äôve heard of the witch hunts in Salem, but I‚Äôm guessing you‚Äôre not as familiar with the pig-man hunts of New Haven.

item.title: Naturalistic fallacy
item.description: Naturalistic fallacy is the assumption that whatever is natural is good, and vice versa. It‚Äôs far too easily based on cherry-picking and nonsense, and is not a solid foundation for ethics. In [[books/perv|Perv]], [[authors/jesse bering|Jesse Bering]] points out that we jump too quickly to the naturalistic fallacy in pursuit of LGBTQ rights:

item.title: The science of pro cycling race numbers
item.description: Here I am, once again trying to explain the arcane logic of race numbers, and the internet is surprisingly unhelpful, offering up only one or two insufficient links before trying to help me print my own race number, pin my own race number, or sign up for triathlons.

item.title: Dull elves
item.description: I‚Äôm going to reference this sooner or later, so I want the full citation. item.title: On firearms, trust and historical accuracy
item.description: There‚Äôs a scene in [[books/a governess‚Äôs guide to passion and peril|A Governess’s Guide to Passion and Peril]] that has stuck in my mind, and I want to write through it to figure out why it‚Äôs niggling at me. item.title: All transmission is recreation
item.description: [[authors/gretchen mcculloch|Gretchen McCulloch]], [[books/because internet|Because Internet]]: A storyteller is a spinner of yarns, and the internet‚Äôs founding metaphor is of [[notes/the internet is a rhizome|a web]]. If we go far enough back, before printing presses and cameras and photocopiers introduced the notion of faithful reproduction, all transmission is re-creation.

item.title: Enshittification
item.description: Cory Doctorow on the enshittification of TikTok: Here is how platforms die: first, they are good to their users; then they abuse their users to make things better for their business customers; finally, they abuse those business customers to claw back all the value for themselves.

item.title: Social media is the third place
item.description: Thinking about public and semipublic posting on social media sites as [[notes/the necessity of third places|third places]] can provide a way of thinking about [[notes/enshittification|the responsibility of a platform to its residents]]: your local bartenders or baristas don‚Äôt generally interfere with your conversations, but they do reserve the right to kick people out if they‚Äôre disturbing other patrons, and this makes the space better as a whole.

item.title: Puzzle-book worldbuilding
item.description: What I call puzzle-book worldbuilding is one of my favorite things to read. It‚Äôs maddening, it‚Äôs challenging. It‚Äôs delightful. It‚Äôs a heady rush of satisfaction when the pieces start to click. It‚Äôs completely different from worldbuilding that stays dense, illogical, and nonsensical. A lazy author not even bothering to build a puzzle is detectable at first glance from the author you won‚Äôt be able to understand until the second read.

item.title: Phatic phrases
item.description: Phatic phrases are the phrases that follow a well-worn script, and as long as you don‚Äôt miss the beat, the words themselves don‚Äôt matter. For example: Hi! What‚Äôs up? Fine, how are you? Not much. Each person is responding to questions that weren‚Äôt asked, but the script is so familiar and the beats so ingrained that nobody notices.

item.title: The necessity of third places
item.description: Ray Oldenberg coined the term ‚Äúthird place‚Äù in 1989 to describe our social centers. In the OG definition, the first place is home, the second place is work. The third place is a shared place to socialize that‚Äôs neither home nor work, distinguished by conversation and [[notes/play gives meaning to life|playfulness]], familiar faces but no formal membership, freedom to come and go as you please, home away from home.

item.title: All fiction is fanfiction
item.description: You knooooow I will get on this soapbox all day long. [[notes/fanfiction is literature|All fiction is fanfiction]]. All art is fan art. Long before we had the (very super recent modern) idea that a book = a discrete, permanent object, we had [[collective folk texts]] that spread precisely because people remixed and remade them.

item.title: Amateur
item.description: A proposition: what if amateur could outrank professional in terms of our respect? We tend to use amateur pejoratively, to indicate the lack of skill, but the word in French means lover. If you think about it this way: Amateur: one who loves Professional: one who is financially obligated

item.title: Collective folk texts
item.description: [[authors/gretchen mcculloch|Gretchen McCulloch]], [[books/because internet|Because Internet]]: Both memes and needlework are collective folk texts that spread because people remix and remake them. The words ‚Äútext‚Äù and ‚Äútextile‚Äù have a common origin, from a Proto-Indo-European root teks, ‚Äúto weave.‚Äù Writing and weaving are both acts of creation by bringing together.

item.title: Everything is fiction
item.description: Everything is Fiction, Keith Ridgeway: And I mean that‚Äîeverything is fiction. When you tell yourself the story of your life, the story of your day, you edit and rewrite and weave a narrative out of a collection of random experiences and events. Your conversations are fiction.

item.title: Fanfiction is literature
item.description: Since Tumblr posts are disappearing faster than the Amazon rainforest, I want to archive this for posterity: I think fanfiction is literature and literature, for the most part, is fanfiction, and that anyone that dismisses it simply on the grounds that it‚Äôs derivative knows fuck-all about literature and needs to get the hell off my lawn.

item.title: Language is a network
item.description: [[authors/gretchen mcculloch|Gretchen McCulloch]], [[books/because internet|Because Internet]]: When we thought of language like a book, we thought of it as an unruly mess of words that had to be kept in order, like a Victorian gardener constantly retrimming the hedges into spirals and globes. When we think of language like a network, we can see order as a thing that [[notes/emergence|emerges]] out of the natural tendencies of the individuals, the way that [[books/the hidden life of trees|a forest keeps itself in order]] even though it doesn‚Äôt get pruned and weeded.

item.title: Mosaic novel
item.description: [[authors/jo walton|Jo Walton]], in the foreward for [[books/china mountain zhang|China Mountain Zhang]], discusses the difference between books of interconnected short stories vs. mosaic novels. A normal novel tells a story by going straightforwardly at it, maybe with different points of view, maybe braided, but clearly going down one road of story.

item.title: Pleasure is therapeutic
item.description: In Who Gets to Medicate Me?, Jesse Meadows (@sluggish) interrogates the cultural, puritanical idea that pleasure is destructive. Psychoactive drugs have direct effects on us, and sometimes those effects feel good, which can be helpful in itself. Puritanical thought and anti-drug propaganda have led us to think of pleasure as destructive, but pleasure can be therapeutic, too.

item.title: The culturally bound notion of authorship
item.description: [[authors/gretchen mcculloch|Gretchen McCulloch]], [[books/because internet|Because Internet]]: Our modern, Western notion that authorship should be solo and original is comparatively young and culturally bound, dating back only to after we had the ability to make faithful and exact copies at a mass scale. Copyright started evolving into its modern form in the centuries after the invention of the printing press made copying easy.

item.title: Karass
item.description: A group of people linked in a cosmically significant manner, even when superficial linkages are not evident. Coined by [[authors/kurt vonnegut|Kurt Vonnegut]] in 1963, as a Bokononist term in the novel [[books/cats cradle|Cat‚Äôs Cradle]]. Other karass-related terms: duprass ‚Äì a karass of only two people, who almost always die within a week of each other.

item.title: Apophatic naming
item.description: Apophatic naming, or negative naming, is the attempt to call a thing by so many names that its essential nature transcends all of them. It‚Äôs a practice ‚Äúas old as philosophy itself,‚Äù1 and a central element of mysticism and early Christian thought. I like the turn of phrase in this one: the Mystical Languages of Unsaying.

item.title: Bottom-up processing
item.description: Top-down thinkers have a linear thought process, a deductive approach, a ‚Äúconcept-before-the-details‚Äù type brain. Bottom-up thinkers have an associative thought process, an inductive approach, a ‚Äúdetails-before-the-concept‚Äù type brain. [[notes/autism|Autistic people]] tend to belong overwhelmingly to the second category.1 Instead of fitting new information into a preexisting box, contextualizing based on prior knowledge‚Äìor even constrained by prior knowledge‚Äìthe autistic mind takes in a bombardment of details and sorts it into a comprehensible picture.

item.title: Bibliotropic
item.description: To leans towards a book as flowers leans toward the sun. I‚Äôm guessing [[authors/jo walton|Jo Walton]] didn‚Äôt coin this one so much as borrow it, but most of the top results in google reference [[books/among others|her use of it]], or at least the SFF community.

item.title: You are the process
item.description: [[authors/alan watts|Alan Watts]], in [[books/out of your mind|Out of Your Mind]]: If there was a big bang at the beginning of¬†time, you are not something that is the result of that¬†explosion at the end of the process. You are the process. You are the big bang.

item.title: Worthy victims
item.description: Is one reason that we commemorate the Holocaust to the extent that we do because they were compliant victims? There was resistance in the form of escape, but not armed conflict. No brutal violence in return. Is it that same concept as [[notes/english poor laws|the worthy poor]], determining who deserves our sympathy and who doesn‚Äôt?

item.title: You‚Äôre a wiggle
item.description: [[authors/alan watts|Alan Watts]] in [[books/out of your mind|Out of Your Mind]]: See, the physical world is wiggly. Clouds, mountains, trees, people‚Äîeverything is wiggly. It‚Äôs only when¬†human beings get working on things that they build¬†buildings in straight lines and try to make the world¬†unwiggly.

item.title: What‚Äôs the point if we can‚Äôt have fun?
item.description: In the essay What‚Äôs the point if we can‚Äôt have fun?, [[authors/david graeber|David Graeber]] argues that we‚Äôre fools for focusing on rational explanations and economic terms in animal behavior, and for undervaluing play. Why do animals play? Why does the existence of action carried out for the sheer pleasure of acting strike us as mysterious?

item.title: Who is more deserving
item.description: As if deserving meant anything. As if one could earn beauty, or life! ([[authors/ursula k le guin|Ursula K. Le Guin]], [[books/the dispossessed|The Dispossessed]]) Over on Sluggish, Jesse Meadows is talking about people getting ruffled ‚Äú because everyone online is autistic now.‚Äù It‚Äôs just the latest hand-wringing over [[notes/autism|autism]] as an internet trend (or insert any ‚Äú-ism as an internet trend‚Äù), and the key argument is that the right people aren‚Äôt getting what they deserve, while ‚Äúfakers‚Äù are taking resources away.

item.title: Vorfreude
item.description: The German word vorfruede has no English equivalent. It comes from the words vor (‚Äúbefore‚Äù) and Freude (‚Äújoy‚Äù) and means something along the lines of ‚Äújoyful anticipation.‚Äù Often ‚Äúvorfreude‚Äù is characterized as childish anticipation. It also includes the tension, impatience, and curiosity of anticipating an event.

item.title: We are symptomatic of the universe
item.description: [[authors/alan watts|Alan Watts]] in [[books/out of your mind|Out of Your Mind]]: If there is any such thing as intelligence or love or¬†beauty, you find it in other people. Those things exist in¬†human beings, and if they exist in us, it means that intelligence and love and beauty are symptomatic of the¬†scheme of things.

item.title: The internet is a rhizome
item.description: [[authors/gretchen mcculloch|Gretchen McCulloch]], [[books/because internet|Because Internet]]: When we thought of language as a book, we thought of it as linear and finite. A book can only have so many pages, so you have to decide what to keep in, what to fence out, and how to order what remains.

item.title: The theology of capitalism
item.description: We have mostly forgotten to be surprised that a street preacher‚Äôs followers discovered, several hundred years after his death, how to be a regimented multinational corporate enterprise. ([[books/pagans|Pagans]], [[authors/james o’donnell|James J. O‚ÄôDonnell]]) In [[books/all about love|All About Love]], [[authors/bell hooks|bell hooks]] (via Erich Fromm) says the principle underlying capitalistic society and the principle of love are incompatible.

item.title: The trust checklist
item.description: Trust is more of a cognitive assessment than an emotion. Distrust is when you feel ‚Äúwhat is important to me is not safe with this person.‚Äù That lack of safety makes authenticity and vulnerability difficult for fear of betrayal (rightly so!). In [[books/atlas of the heart|Atlas of the Heart]], [[authors/bren√© brown|Bren√© Brown]] lists seven specific trustworthy behaviors:

item.title: The Carrier Bag Theory of Fiction
item.description: by [[authors/ursula k le guin|Ursula K. Le Guin]] Ed. note: just me copying and annotating this text in full, it‚Äôs that brilliant. In the temperate and tropical regions where it appears that hominids evolved into human beings, the principal food of the species was vegetable.

item.title: The curse of Latin-y grammar
item.description: The Latin-worshipping tradition is responsible for the grammar elitism of infinitive splitting, proposition ending, and the singular ‚Äúthey.‚Äù Robert Lowth, who wrote a widely used English grammar in 1792, passed an aesthetic judgment on the sentence-ending preposition (it wasn‚Äôt Latin-y enough), and later grammarians elevated this preference to a full-on ban.

item.title: Rhizomatic thinking
item.description: Rhizome, from the ancient Greek: a mass of roots. In botany, it describes a plant system that extends roots and shoots from its nodes in every direction. The rhizome was adopted as a philosophical concept to describe a process of existence and growth with no clear hierarchy or single central point of origin.

item.title: Science fiction futures
item.description: I would call our work to change the world ‚Äúscience fictional behavior‚Äù‚Äîbeing concerned with the way our actions and beliefs now, today, will shape the future, tomorrow, the next generations. Science fiction is simply a way to practice the future together. I suspect that is what many of you are up to, practicing futures together, practicing justice together, living into new stories.

item.title: Play gives meaning to life
item.description: Play gives meaning to life, wrote the Dutch historian Johan Huizinga back in 1938. He christened us homo ludens‚Äî‚Äòplaying man.‚Äô Everything we call ‚Äòculture,‚Äô said Huizinga, originates in play.1 Almost all mammals play, and many other animals can‚Äôt resist. It‚Äôs the most intelligent animals that exhibit the most playful behavior.

item.title: Playfulness vs. epistemic traps
item.description: A pre-print by C. Thi Nguyen, full download here.

item.title: Multiple intelligence theory
item.description: Howard Gardner first outlined his theory in his 1983 book Frames of Mind, where he suggested that all people have different kinds of intelligence. He proposed that there are eight intelligences, and has suggested the possible addition of a ninth known as ‚Äúexistentialist intelligence.‚Äù Linguistic intelligence‚Äîa deep-rooted understanding and nuanced use of language, a proficiency that goes beyond fluency.

item.title: Mitfreude
item.description: Mitfreude is feeling joy in another‚Äôs joy. The opposite of schadenfreude, where pleasure is derived from another‚Äôs misfortune. Coined by Nietzsche in 1878,1 it originates in the German language, mit (‚Äúwith‚Äù) + Freude (‚Äújoy‚Äù). First encountered in [[authors/ada palmer|Ada Palmer]]‚Äôs essay on anime and manga, A Mitfreude of Anime and Manga‚Äôs Relationship with Anglophone Science Fiction), where she defines it as the joy of sharing joy with friends.

item.title: Memes and social movements
item.description: [[authors/gretchen mcculloch|Gretchen McCulloch]], [[books/because internet|Because Internet]]: ‚ÄúWhy do games like FarmVille and Pok√©mon Go periodically sweep social media? In a previous decade, games like gin rummy and pool, which are conducive to lively conversation, were characteristic of third places. Oldenburg also points out how ==third places have been essential to forming the kinds of large, loose-knit social groups that are the core of new social movements==, such as the agora in ancient Greek democracy, taverns around the American Revolution, and coffeeshops during the Age of Enlightenment, which parallels how Twitter was used for the Arab Spring or the Black Lives Matter protests.

item.title: Linguistic play as a writing exercise
item.description: [[authors/gretchen mcculloch|Gretchen McCulloch]], [[books/because internet|Because Internet]]: I‚Äôve taken up this sense of linguistic play as a writing exercise, especially when I‚Äôve just read a bunch of academic papers and I‚Äôm having trouble shaking my thoughts free of Nominalization Accumulation Enunciation Contamination. Instead, I draft in Peak Internet Style, with no capitalization or punctuation, using acronyms and creative respelling to write my way through the muddle, rather than stopping when I don‚Äôt know how to articulate something or trying to sort through form and content at the same time.

item.title: Institutional betrayal
item.description: Institutional betrayal is when an institution causes harm (by action or inaction) to anyone who trusts or depends on them. Red flags include strict membership requirements (the military, elite sports), prestige or power differentials (caregivers v. patients, clergy v. parishioners), and rigid priorities, like extreme efforts to protect the reputation of the organization.

item.title: Humanitas/humus
item.description: Humanitas in Latin comes first and properly from humando, meaning ‚Äòburying, burial‚Äô, itself from humus, meaning ‚Äòearth‚Äô or ‚Äòsoil.‚Äô In burial, the human body becomes a component of the earth, returned as dust to dust‚Äîinhumed, restored to humility, rendered humble. [[books/underland|Underland]], [[authors/robert macfarlane|Robert Macfarlane]]

item.title: Glimmering
item.description: The opposite of a trigger. A little glimmering of affirmation. First encountered on IG, @tialevings and others

item.title: Emergence
item.description: Faced with the puzzle of how life might emerge from dead matter or how conscious beings might evolve from microbes, philosophers of science have developed the theory of emergence. The argument here is that once a certain level of complexity is reached, there is a kind of qualitative leap where completely new sorts of physical laws can ‚Äúemerge‚Äù‚Äîones that are premised on, but cannot be reduced to, what came before.

item.title: Emotional identification
item.description: Broadly speaking, we experience three different kinds of emotions in our brains: reactive, routine, and reflective emotions. Reactive emotions are primitive, hardwired, and innate emotions, such as fear and defensive rage, produced in response to a perceived threat. They energize us for fight-and-flight and live in our limbic system.

item.title: The Chinese word for endurance
item.description: In [[books/what my bones know|What My Bones Know]], [[authors/stephanie foo|Stephanie Foo]] says: It made perfect sense to me later in life when I discovered that the Chinese word for endurance is simply the word knife on top of the word heart. item.title: Debility and disability justice

item.title: Concepts of time
item.description: The Greeks had two different conceptions of time: chronos (quantitative, linear) and kairos (qualitative, nonlinear). Ancient Indians had a similar conception of time: kala (quantitative) and ritu (qualitative). [[notes/deep time|Deep time]] (also called geological time, cosmological time, or radiological time) involves the time scale of geologic events, which is incomparably vast compared to the time scale of human history.

item.title: Manifest Destiny
item.description: Manifest Destiny, an event of Westward Expansion from the Wild West In the 19th century US, Manifest Destiny was a belief that was widely held that the destiny of American settlers was to expand and move across the continent to spread their traditions and their institutions, while at the same time ==enlightening more primitive nations==.
